_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Compressors, Vessels, Spiral Freezer, Evaporative Condenser

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP/PSM Program Management



Home Run Inn has developed a management system to oversee the implementation of the RMP/PSM Program elements.  This includes assigning a qualified person (or position) to have overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the Program.  If any portion of the Program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals need to be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document. 



Home Run Inn Management Commitment and Organization Structure 

The Home Run Inn management team fully supports the implementation of the RMP/PSM Program developed for this facility and is one of many established safety programs.  This document describes the responsibilities of the various personnel involved with each of the program elements.  The following is the main hierarchy structure for the implementation of this program and the key personnel involved and their responsibilities with the anhydrous ammonia system and the RMP/PSM Program:



President

The President provides the authority and budget as necessary to implement this Program for the protection of all employees. 



Plant Manager  

The Plant Manager supports and ensures that all elements of this Program are implemented completely for the protection of all employees.  The Plant Manager is responsible and accountable for the overall implementation and maintenance of the Program.  The Plant Manager is responsible for the general safety training and documentation to support facility operations.  This position will ensure safety training under the Program is conducted and documented appropriately.



Maintenance Department Employees  

Maintenance Department employees are defined as those personnel that may start-up/shuts-down, make adjustments/repairs or otherwise affect the ammonia refrigeration covered process equipment.  These persons will require specific training on the details of the RMP/PSM Program

and its requirements.  Their main responsibilities are spelled out in each section within this Program, but in general is to comply with the requirements set forth in this written document.





Policies To Protect Health, Environment, and Safety

Risk management and safety are important concerns at Home Run Inn. This RMP formalizes and documents these activities. Home Run Inn is committed to conducting its operations in a safe and responsible manner thereby reducing risks to human health and the environment. It is Home Run Inn?s policy to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local rules and regulations.



This RMP has identified potential hazards and has taken steps to design and maintain a safe facility in order to prevent releases, and minimize the consequences of accidental releases, which could occur. RMP addresses a potentially catastrophic chemical release that could result in immediate harm and acute health effects to offsite receptors (public and environmental). The RMP includes a Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that contains procedures that are designed to maximize the safety of all employees, contractors, and visitors in the event of an emergency and also guard against environmental consequences.



Although ammonia is a listed toxic substance, it is also a ubiquitous material, which is used by the surrounding farmers for fertilizer. Pursuant to 40 CFR 68.125 Exemptions ? Ammonia used as an agricultural nutrient, when held by farmers, is exempt from all provisions of this part (40 CFR 68).



Facility Identification and Process Description

The Home Run Inn facility is located at 1300 Internationale Parkway, Woodridge, Illinois 60517. The  of the property is approximately seven (7) acres and the ammonia refrigeration system resides in one (1) building. 



There are 101 employees that work at the plant.



The facility is primarily engaged in the business of producing frozen pizzas. The North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code

for the processes at the facility is 311412.  The Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) code for the processes at the facility is 2038. 



The process area of the facility is located at:

Latitude: 41 deg. 41 min. 50 sec. North

Longitude: -88 deg. 00 min. 54 sec. West 



Anyhydrous ammonia is the material used in the frozen pizza refrigeration system.  The system has a total capacity of 15000 pounds.  The largest vessel located inside the building (HTRP-1) may contain as much as 6600 pounds.   



Accidental Release Prevention Program

RMP/PSM Prevention Program provides information and procedures to prevent or minimize an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. The following ammonia refrigeration process equipment is covered: piping, condensers, evaporators, compressors, etc. The next compliance audit of the RMP/PSM Program will occured in July, 2016 (three (3) years). The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) shall be updated and revalidated no later than August of 2022 (five (5) years pursuant to the 29 CFR 1910.119(e)(6). The elements of the RMP/PSM Prevention Program along with a brief description are listed below:



Employee Participation ? Home Run Inn has developed a site-specific Employee Participation Program (EPP) that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the RMP/PSM regulation. In addition, the EPP ensures employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under RMP/PSM. Employees at Home Run Inn have assisted in developing the initial PHA for the ammonia refrigeration process and will participate in updating and revalidating the PHA every five (5) years.  In addition, employees have assisted in the development of other RMP/PSM documentation such as the development of operating and preventative maintenance procedures.



Process Safety Information (PSI)

? Home Run Inn has developed a PSI Program to ensure that site-specific PSI pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the ammonia refrigeration process are properly developed and maintained. PSI enables Home Run Inn employees and contractors to identify and understand the potential hazards in the ammonia refrigeration system. The written information includes the ammonia MSDS and a description of the design of the ammonia refrigeration system. 



Process Hazard Review (PHA) ? Home run Inn has developed a site-specific PHA Program which is a formal study designed to analyze the process and identify potential hazards. In addition, this program has been established to ensure PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and to ensure findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. A What if/Checklist approach was taken. 



Operating Procedures ? Home run Inn has developed site-specific written operating procedures that provide detailed, clear instructions describing the steps that should be followed to safely operate the ammonia refrigeration system. 



Training ? Home run Inn has developed a site-specific Training Program that ensures employees operating the ammonia refrigeration process have the knowledge to safely operate all aspects of the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the potential causes of process problems. This Program identifies the duties that employees should perform to ensure the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system. 



Contractors ? Home Run Inn has developed a site-specific Contractor Safety Program. All Home Run Inn contractors will be screened and evaluated before they perform work on or near the ammonia refrigeration system. The Program ensures that all contract employers? safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Home Run Inn a

nd the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the Emergency Action Plan and control over entrance into process areas.



Management of Change (MOC) ? Home Run Inn has developed a site-specific Management of Change Program to ensure that all changes made to the ammonia refrigeration system are properly reviewed, documented, and communicated to employees, contractors, and management team. The MOC Procedure ensures that changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented and communicated. 



Pre-startup Review (PSSR) ? Home run Inn has developed a site-specific Pre-startup Safety Review Program that is completed for all new ammonia projects to verify that all safety programs are in place, training has been performed, and construction has been completed according to design standards before the process is started. A PSSR is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.



Mechanical Integrity (MI) ? Home Run Inn has developed a site-specific Mechanical Integrity Program that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training. The MI Program ensures that the ammonia refrigeration system is built, used, and maintained using preventive maintenance procedures to minimize unexpected breakdowns or failures.  



Incident Investigation ? Home Run Inn has developed a site-specific Incident Investigation Program that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated within 48 hours. This Program ensures that any incidents are investigated, reviewed, and documented using an investigation team including at

least one person knowledgeable in the process. This Program also makes provisions to ensure that a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly reviewed and addressed.

 

Compliance Audit ? Home Run Inn has developed a site-specific Compliance Audit Program to ensure that compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Home Run Inn?s PSM/RMP Program is in place and working properly; and that practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed. The Compliance Audit Program also ensures that regular audits are performed. 



Hot Work Permits ? Home Run Inn has developed and implemented a Best Management Practice for hot work. This BMP ensures that a signed permit is obtained prior to any cutting, welding, or burning.





Emergency Response Program

Home Run Inn has an Emergency Response Plans in place for responding to emergencies and contains the following sections:



Communication Procedure

Evacuation Procedure

Alarm Procedure

Emergency Assistance Phone Numbers

Chemical Spill Emergency Phone Numbers

Personnel Emergency Phone Numbers

Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases;

Documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures; and

Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release of a regulated substance;

Training for all employees in relevant procedures; and

Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes at the stationary source and ensure that employees are informed of changes.

   

   

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Home Run Inn is proactive with regard to further improving chemical safety at the facility. Home Run Inn conducted a Process Hazard Analysis and will be dutifully implementing the recommendations from that audit. Additionally, an ammonia detection with sensors loc
ated at key locations has been implemented.  The anhydrous ammonia system also has an emergency dump that would mix the ammonia with water to control a potential incident.
